DOC.HEAD: Freeze Fears Power Limit Gains In Orange Juice Market
DOC.TEXT: Forecasts for a frosty weekend in Florida's citrus belt drove orange juice futures prices up sharply Tuesday while harsh winter weather in the North spurred the heating-oil market to greater gains. On other commodity markets Tuesday, grains and soybeans, livestock and meat, and precious-metals futures were mixed. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled 5 cents to 5.4 cents higher on the New York Cotton Exchange with the contract for delivery in January at $1.3245 a pound. Orange juice futures normally are limited to daily moves of 5 cents but the limit on the January contract has been lifted pending the contract's upcoming expiration. The runup reflected predictions for freezing temperatures Saturday and Sunday night in the Florida citrus region, the result of an intensifying cold air mass that shattered records in the Northern Plains on Tuesday and was working its way east and south. The severity and timing of the cold wave are reminiscent of a deep freeze that badly damaged the Flordia orange crop six years ago, said Celeste Georkakis, an analyst in New York with Cargill Investor Services Inc. Nevertheless, she said, ``being that weather forecasters have been predicting freezes all along, the growers will be better prepared than in 1983, when the freeze came on Christmas Eve.'' A hard freeze forecast for the citrus country last week failed to materialize. Freezing temperatures touched only the northernmost edge of the citrus groves. Heating-oil for near-term delivery rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the third straight day and the 14th time in the last 15 sessions, still supported by strong, weather-driven demand for increasingly tight supplies. Crude-oil futures finished mixed after a day of erratic price swings linked to the expiration of the January contract, which went off the board 11 cents higher at $22.33 a barrel. Gasoline and deferred deliveries of heating oil finished lower. An American Petroleum Institute report released after the close showed a 1.7-million-barrel reduction in U.S. stocks of petroleum distillates last week while inventories of crude oil rose 4.1 million barrels and gasoline stocks rose by 3.6 million barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 15 cents lower to 11 cents higher with February at $21.28 a barrel; heating oil was .94 cent lower to .35 cent higher with January at 75.01 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .58 cent to 1.2 cents lower with January at 53.93 cents a gallon. Wheat futures prices rose modestly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade on indications that China had bid for 410,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Corn closed mixed and soybean futures finished lower. After the close, the Agriculture Department announced it had targeted the Soviet Union for sales of 2 million metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices, which could prompt further buying of wheat futures Wednesday. All grain contracts for December deliveries expired at noon Central time. December wheat went off the board 4 cents lower at $4.11 a bushel, December corn was 1 cent lower at $2.33{ a bushel and December oats were 2 cents lower at $1.40 a bushel. There was no December soybean contract. Wheat futures settled } cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $4.14\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $2.38} a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $1.52{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with January at $5.78{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures finished mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with cattle mostly higher, boosted by strong cash fundamentals. Live cattle futures settled .07 cent lower to .78 cent higher with December at 78.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .43 cent higher with January at 84.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .27 cent higher with December at 53.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .53 cent lower with February at 51.60 cents a pound. Gold futures ended nearly unchanged on New York's Commodity Exchange while silver futures slipped moderately. Gold settled unchanged to .10 cent higher with December at $411.90 a troy ounce; silver was 3.8 cents to 5.5 cents lower with December at $5.527 a troy ounce.
